author: Brandon Schwartz
bottom_line: Today's intense solar heating and high sun angles are expected to create avalanche problems associated with rapid warming across all aspects today. Avalanche problems will become increasingly problematic as the day progresses. The best bet is to time travel in avalanche terrain during the morning hours and to consider avoiding avalanche terrain during the afternoon hours.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
It's April and the sun angles are now high enough to create wet snow on all aspects. Rapid warming of the 2 to 6 inches of new snow from the past 24 hours is expected to lead to wet loose avalanches occurring on all aspects today. Long open slopes with sustained slope angles will have the potential to create the largest wet loose avalanches as more snow becomes entrained following the initial point release.

Rollerballs and pinwheels are indications that this avalanche problem is present. Consider moving to slopes less steep than about 35 degrees in slope angle to reduce the risk of becoming caught in a wet loose avalanche.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
A natural cornice fall cycle is possible starting today, increasing in likelihood tomorrow through Monday. Some of the cornices out there near treeline and above treeline on N-NE-E aspects range in size from very large to massive. Falling blocks of very dense snow will have some destructive potential.

The exact moment that a cornice fall will occur is nearly impossible to predict and is often larger than expected. Nearly everyone involved in a cornice fall incident while on a ridgetop is caught by surprise when the cornice breaks off much further back from the edge than expected. Stay well back from cornice areas on ridgetops and consider avoiding travel on slopes underneath cornices.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Cornice Fall
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Cornice Fall is the release of an overhanging mass of snow that forms as the wind moves snow over a sharp terrain feature, such as a ridge, and deposits snow on the downwind (leeward) side. Cornices range in size from small wind drifts of soft snow to large overhangs of hard snow that are 30 feet (10 meters) or taller. They can break off the terrain suddenly and pull back onto the ridge top and catch people by surprise even on the flat ground above the slope. Even small cornices can have enough mass to be destructive and deadly. Cornice Fall can entrain loose surface snow or trigger slab avalanches.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Rapid warming today may increase the instability of wind slabs that formed yesterday in locations where wind drifted snow was deposited near ridgetops and into gully features. Cornice fall may also trigger wind slab avalanches today.

Use clues such as cornices, wind drifts, snow surface texture, recent avalanches, and snow surface cracking to identify areas where problematic wind slabs may exist. Move cautiously around these areas and consider avoiding slopes below cornice features.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.
